name: dwAvgBytesPerSec
desc: For PCM data, the wAvgBytesPerSec field of the ‘fmt’ chunk should be equal to the following formula rounded up to the next whole number: wChannels x wBitsPerSecond x ( wBitsPerSample / 8 )

name: wBlockAlign
desc: The wBlockAlign field should be equal to the following formula, rounded to the next whole number: wChannels x ( wBitsPerSample / 8 )

name: value
desc: Archival Location. Indicates where the subject of the file is archived.

name: value
desc: Genre. Describes the original work, such as "landscape", "portrait", "still life", etc.

name: value
desc: Keywords. Provides a list of keywords that refer to the file or subject of the file. Separate multiple keywords with a semicolon and a blank. For example, "Seattle; aerial view; scenery".

name: value
desc: Lightness. Describes the changes in lightness settings on the digitizer required to produce the file. Note that the format of this information depends on hardware used.

name: value
desc: Medium. Describes the original subject of the file, such as "computer image", "drawing", "lithograph", and so forth.

name: value
desc: Name. Stores the title of the subject of the file, such as "Seattle From Above".

name: value
desc: Palette Setting. Specifies the number of colors requested when digitizing an image, such as "256".

name: value
desc: Product. Specifies the name of the title the file was originally intended for, such as "Encyclopedia of Pacific Northwest Geography".

name: value
desc: Subject. Describes the contents of the file, such as "Aerial view of Seattle".

name: value
desc: Software. Identifies the name of the software package used to create the file, such as "Microsoft WaveEdit".

name: value
desc: Sharpness. Identifies the changes in sharpness for the digitizer required to produce the file (the format depends on the hardware used).

name: value
desc: Artist. Lists the artist of the original subject of the file. For example, "Michaelangelo".

name: value
desc: Source. Identifies the name of the person or organization who supplied the original subject of the file. For example, "Trey Research".

name: value
desc: Source Form. Identifies the original form of the material that was digitized, such as "slide", "paper", "map", and so forth. This is not necessarily the same as IMED.

name: value
desc: Technician. Identifies the technician who digitized the subject file. For example, "Smith, John."

name: value
desc: Commissioned. Lists the name of the person or organization that commissioned the subject of the file. For example, "Pope Julian II".

name: value
desc: Comments. Provides general comments about the file or the subject of the file. If the comment is several sentences long, end each sentence with a period. Do not include newline characters.

name: value
desc: Copyright. Records the copyright information for the file. For example, "Copyright Encyclopedia International 1991." If there are multiple copyrights, separate them by a semicolon followed by a space.

name: value
desc: Creation date. Specifies the date the subject of the file was created. List dates in year-month-day format, padding one-digit months and days with a zero on the left. For example, "1553-05-03" for May 3, 1553.

name: value
desc: Cropped. Describes whether an image has been cropped and, if so, how it was cropped. For example, "lower right corner". IDIM Dimensions. Specifies the size of the original subject of the file. For example, "8.5 in h, 11 in w".

name: value
desc: Dots Per Inch. Stores dots per inch setting of the digitizer used to produce the file, such as "300".

name: value
desc: Engineer. Stores the name of the engineer who worked on the file. If there are multiple engineers, separate the names by a semicolon and a blank. For example, "Smith, John; Adams, Joe".

name: wCodePage
desc: Specifies the code page used for file elements. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if this field has value zero, assume standard ISO 8859/1 code page (identical to code page 1004 without code points defined in hex columns 0, 1, 8, and 9).

name: wCountryCode
desc: Specifies the country code used for file elements. See “ Country Codes,” following this section, for a list of currently defined country codes. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if this field has value zero, assume USA (country code 001).

name: wLanguage
desc: Specify the language and dialect used for file elements. See “Language and Dialect Codes,” later in this chapter, for a list of language and dialect codes. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if these fields have value zero, assume US English (language code 9, dialect code 1).

name: wDialect
desc: Specify the language and dialect used for file elements. See “Language and Dialect Codes,” later in this chapter, for a list of language and dialect codes. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if these fields have value zero, assume US English (language code 9, dialect code 1).

name: code_page
desc: Specifies the code page used for file elements. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if this field has value zero, assume standard ISO 8859/1 code page (identical to code page 1004 without code points defined in hex columns 0, 1, 8, and 9).

name: country_code
desc: Specifies the country code used for file elements. See “ Country Codes,” following this section, for a list of currently defined country codes. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if this field has value zero, assume USA (country code 001).

name: language
desc: Specify the language and dialect used for file elements. See “Language and Dialect Codes,” later in this chapter, for a list of language and dialect codes. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if these fields have value zero, assume US English (language code 9, dialect code 1).

name: dialect
desc: Specify the language and dialect used for file elements. See “Language and Dialect Codes,” later in this chapter, for a list of language and dialect codes. If the CSET chunk is not present, or if these fields have value zero, assume US English (language code 9, dialect code 1).

name: dwFileSize
desc: Number of samples

name: samples
desc: Number of samples. RIFF1991 named this field dwFileSize, even though it's documented as "Number of samples"
